This seems a lot like a "most significant bit" problem, with a slightly
larger alphabet (but still a finite alphabet). The basic idea is to
determine, for each character in the string, whether it is in the
lowercase or uppercase position. To determine this, you can check the
bits in the character itself; or, if you think that's too expensive,
you can just read the bits of the first character and start assuming
that the second character is always in the opposite position.

This is called a "one-liner" in programming lingo. It's a one-line solution, or a one-line function, that can solve the given problem. For example, the first one-liner, _solve_, is a solution to the problem "given a string, reverse its case or keep it as is".
There are many more one-liners in the Python documentation, and many more in the comments of Hacker News.

To me a one-liner is a piece of code that does something that could be written as a one-liner in some language. For example, in C:
while(1) { printf("%s", "\n\n"); }
